Slowbro works well. Modest max HP, max SpA, Iron Defense, Calm Mind, Stored Power, Slack Off, Leftovers/BrightPowder. Set up Iron Defense 2-3 times, Greninja will wipe all of your boosts, set up 3x Iron Defense, 6x Calm Mind, heal with Slack Off occasionally, sweep with Stored Power. Beware of Night Slash crits.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53216865
To solo this Mon and farm it, you want to use:

Kingambit @ Shell Bell
Ability: Supreme Overlord
Tera Type: Dark
EVs: 252 HP / 252 Atk / 4 SpA
Brave Nature
- Kowtow Cleave
- Snarl
- Iron Defense
- Swords Dance

Snarl until your Tera orb is charged (and he wipes your stats) and then swords dance 2-3 times. Then you want to Tera dark and kowtow cleave until it dies. Once you Tera it will start using physical moves. This is the most reliable solo method.

This thread is for the growth of artists and those who draw for fun. If you're going to give critique, please do it constructively. Rude or blunt critiques won't help anybody.

Requesters are free to request what they wish, but avoid bumping your request every half hour as it's only going to put people off; try giving it a few hours or more.

Please provide references in ONE image, especially when requesting something outside of the Pokémon universe. If you request something from the old Drawthread or a separate thread, COPY & PASTE the actual request instead of posting a link.

Also, be mindful that requests are done at the discretion of the artists, not on a first come first serve basis.

Please remember to save any piece of art you like from these threads, as we may never know when the archive will start deleting images again. Artists can and are recommended to post their works on other outlets for archival purposes.

>>53218934
I assume you're asking about my team. I was having so much fun crushing people with the grasshole team from Electric Cup that I decided to turn it into a Love Cup team (also because I didn't want to invest in anything big that I don't already have like Medicham). I used Hisuian Electrode/Crustle/Magcargo, same movesets that PvPoke recommends except I doubled up on rock DPS by giving Magcargo Rock Throw instead of Incinerate. If you play it correctly, you should beat everything that both doesn't use Counter-users (mainly a problem with Medicham, but only Scrafty really shows up in the lower ELOs, which is at least managable) or high-damage charge move spammers (mainly a problem with Octillery and Porygon2, but people tend to lead with those two if they are using them, so it's easy to prepare for them).

VGC is The Pokémon Company International's official tournament series. This Double Battle format has a fluctuating banlist and a different set of clauses than Smogon metagames. Most notably, it only allows you to select 4 out of your 6 Pokémon to send into battle.

VGC2023 is run in various stages throughout the year with varying restrictions during each stage. Each stage will be summarized below.
Play Restrictions

Item Clause: No two Pokémon may hold the same item.
Species Clause: A player's team cannot contain two Pokémon with the same National Pokédex number.
Paldea-born: Pokémon must be natively from the Paldea Region, be it from being caught, bred, or otherwise obtained in Paldea.
Level Limit: Pokémon above Lv. 50 are permitted, but will be auto-leveled to Lv. 50 during battle.
Time Limit: Battles will have a 20-minute overall time limit, 7-minute player-specific time limit, 45-second move time limit, and a 90-second team preview.

Series 2 allows the same Pokémon as Series 1 but paradox Pokemon, those with Quark Drive or Booster Energy, are allowed.

Espathra would be a UUBL lifer if not for Tera. Any Steel type walls it forever, and it has no hope of breaking Gholdengo or Corviknight.

Garganacl can be taunted, Good as Gold blocks Taunt. Paralysis, Toxic, and Burn can be answered by tera, or Rest, Rest/Curse/Iron Defense which can't be taunted if you have Good as Gold.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>53213867
Dynamax isn't even in natdex AG. The entire reason why it became unplayable was because of Assist and Revival Blessing. At the top of the ladder, prankster assist into revival blessing meant you could just keep reviving your mons over and over, and you essentially had to have a dedicated counter just for this specific strategy. People kept asking for revive to be banned, but they can't ban anything in AG, so they just deleted the ladder instead.

Of course, this entire thing is fucking stupid because Assist shouldn't be able to call Revival Blessing in the first place, because it's a blatantly broken strategy. They argued that since Gamefreak didn't program an exception for Assist to call Revival Blessing, it was a-okay. The issue there being that Assist hasn't existed since Gen 8 and Gamefreak wouldn't program an exception for a move that doesn't exist, and Assist is programmed to call moves by default unless a move is explicitly in its blacklist.

>>53211556
I wouldn't say so.
From a certain perspective all turn-based RPGs are easy because all you have to do is select the right options, but there are easier and harder ones.
These are the trophies for the North American PS4 version of Persona 3 Portable.
From a sample size of over 1,000 players, only 12% beat the game. Almost half gave up before the first boss. A few players got all the way to the very end of the game, beat the penultimate boss, and then gave up on the final boss.
For comparison, 84% of Final Fantasy X players finished the first area and 29% beat the final boss. Ryuu ga Gotoku 0, theoretically a harder game because it's an action RPG, had 87% of players beat the first boss and 65% beat the final boss. More players beat the final boss of that game than the first boss of Persona 3.

Megaten designs are also about as creative as Pokemon designs IMO.
There are a lot of Pokemon designs that are essentially "a big crab" "a bigger crab" "an even bigger crab" "a crab with boxing gloves", so compared to that Megaten's penis monsters and fucked up corpses feel somewhat unique if nothing else.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53209523
>Justified in my opinion. Grinding in Pokemon is boring as fuck and the safest way to do it would be battling route 1 shit. Nobody wants to sit through that

The point of a Nuzlocke is not to run optimized strats. It is meant to make the adventure more real by adding consequences that stick. Most Pokémon games are designed with the following in mind:

You’ll get Pokémon needed for the next challenge on your way to the next challenge.

You should expect to fight a certain number of sudo-mandatory battles based on route design that makes you choose different types of trainers and spinner risks.

If you feel the need to grind at all, you’ve messed up the spirit of the game. Honestly, we could fix all of this by making the expectation a Nuzlocke glitchless speedrun. At this point, the only YouTuber Nuzlockes I enjoy are noobs and the deathless runs which actually justify all the planning needed since you can never get knocked out.

>>53215475
See, this is the reasonable take. I’m not defending the games being piss easy, I’m just saying that entire rpg parties receiving exp for battles is an industry standard that GF was sputtering behind on for almost two decades before implementing it. The games need higher difficulty and even difficulty options, but I really don’t think unified exp share is what’s making them so easy. I don’t get how you can go through a game that has like 10 mandatory trainer battles, most of which only have 3 Pokemon, and go “Yep, the party experience is the issue” and not “Wow GameFreak is shit at NPC programming and distribution”. The lack of a universal exp share can make replaying games like GSC or FRLG a real slog, often requiring specific gameplay detours just to get it. I’d rather my whole party be growing along the journey than have to do some sidequest just so that I can level up a single other Pokemon and either let the rest of my team get weak or continuously swap out the exp share. It’s such a normal feature for RPGs, it really shows how domesticated GF made their fans that they genuinely made them yearn for an objectively inferior method of party leveling.

>>53215513
>entire rpg parties receiving exp for battles is an industry standard
In RPGs with it, everything is designed around party wide exp being in place.
The problem is that there's too many variables in Pokemon. In other RPGs you typically just have a party of 6-10 people. That allows them to tailor exp gain so that it works out for most if not everyone.
For some examples of the uncertainties with Pokemon, you don't know if the person playing will put their starter in the PC for a while, you don't know all of the different exp requirements for levels for the mons being used, as some grow more slowly than others, and you don't know if they're even going to catch anything outside of the first couple of routes. That means they have to compensate with the exp share which results in over levelling, compared to how it doesn't do that in a game like Persona 5 where it's a lot more set in stone with the party members that party wide exp works.

No, you’re misunderstanding my answer. Functionally, every RPG is one unit at a time if it’s not local coop. It doesn’t matter if you have a party of one, a player controlling a party of 6, or if you’re playing as an army of 5000 unique party members, the “unit” is irrelevant because it’s always a 1 on 1 game, you’re always the one leading your party. Pokemon is not in a unique position. You could argue for the option to turn off Exp All, but there is absolutely 0 logic to how the old Exp Share works, the current set up is the correct way to handle experience regardless of the “unit”. Whether you’ve got no one or the whole world by your side, it’s still always the player fixed in whatever point in the story they’re in, their party members should be scaled to where they’re at. posts.name: Anonymous

>>53215909
The potential to powerlevel only the starter and nothing else has certainly been an issue since the early days.
But if you had access to modern Exp.Share in FRLG and played in the same way, you wouldn't suddenly not have a level 36 Charizard. You'd have a level 36 Charizard with the rest of the team in the high 20s, because the Exp.Share generates extra XP out of thin air.
If it were akin to other RPGs, then Exp.Share would function more like Exp.All, where rather than giving 100% to the Charizard and a bonus 50% to everyone else, the experience would be split evenly, making it so that the entire team would be in the 20s, and forcing you to grind or box some team members if you wanted to try and power-level.

Unquestionably Exp.Share is making an easy game even easier, because on the off-chance that an overleveled starter actually faints, you have a full team of backups that you didn't even need to train that are probably on par with your opponent. The minimal risk that was there is gone completely.
Removing Exp.Share wouldn't suddenly fix the problem you're talking about, but it's one of several steps that would need to be taken in order for the games to get towards something that even starts to resemble a challenge.

>Gen 7
I'll give you this one. The exp share is still pretty broken, but the alola games (especially USUM) do a lot to make up for the lack of challenge. The heavy linearity makes the exp scaling actually work as intended and keep you from becoming EGREGIOUSLY overleveled at the very least. In addtion, the totem battles being 2 on 1 and giving the totem mon a free boost at the beginning, as well as the NPCs just having generally better AI and teams, all combine to make levels less broken than they ever were. You can be pretty overleveled (and you likely will be with the exp share on) and still get fucked up by a poor match up against a specific challenge. That said, it has the least involved exploration and out-of-battle decision making in any pokemon game. Kinda the inverse of gen 9 actually.

But I still think gens 1-5 have an edge that gens 6+ lack. They were just overall less casual experiences, even stuff like items being less plentiful and your team options being more limited make a difference in how the games feel overall.

>>53201884
decided to backtrack and post story from then anyways
-
It'd been about a week since Hannah's solitary triumph at Elesa's gym. By now, the group were ready to move on from Nimbasa, and leave it and Tex behind.

They crossed the Dritfveil bridge, exchanging pleasantries and trying to make their circumstances slightly less awkward, eventually arriving where they'd initially intended to end up...
...Driftveil.

The city was... a little less spectacular than Pillow had imagined. Mostly a collection of warehouses and large one-story homes. The most notable building to its name was the church on a hill in the north, and maybe the mines even further north than that.

Regardless of its plain qualities, Pillow was... relieved. Relieved to be here. She'd accomplished something, and this city was quaint- much unlike the hustle and bustle of the last few they'd visited. The change was quite refreshing, and such a sentiment was soon echoed by Sylvia.

The group promptly split, just for a moment. Tea and Hairdo wanted to find where the gym was, while Sylvia and Pillow decided to go and hang out near the Cold Storage in the north. Hannah tagged along for the company, though she didn't talk much.

When the girls got there, however, they were given plenty to talk about.
That Beheeyem pair and their Braviary boss could be spotted once again, up on a podium and seemingly trying to rile up the Pokemon living there- spouting untruths about how Pokemon had been treated as second-class citizens, and citing the contempt the workers of the Storage had for the wilds living there. The tactic seemed to be working, as the small crowd of mon that'd gathered around the mysterious trio seemed rather loud and excited.

So excited, in fact, that a Herdier in the crowd quickly took notice of the newcomers I've been documenting and rushed to hold up Hannah specifically as an example.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53204714
"Look, look!" the Herdier exclaimed, holding up a claw to the Bolt badge shining on Hannah's shoulder. "You're right, Mr Ghetsis sir! This Boldore even has a badge bolted right into her shoulder!"
An ineffectual paw at the accessory yielded little movement, prompting the dog to continue with a slightly more disgusted expression. "I bet her trainer forced her to fight until she was exhausted, and made the badge this way so that he could show off!"

This stranger was, of course, smacked away by Hannah soon after. The only reason she hadn't done so sooner was purely due to how tired she was after Nimbasa. In that respect, the Herdier had a point. Hannah could really use some time to rest after that.

The Braviary called back, though, a grin forming on his beak as the entire crowd turned to the new trio. He quickly affirmed the Herdier's train of thought, giving a sharp nod toward the Herdier and continuing to make an example of Hannah. "Truly despicable behavior. But it's to be expected from humankind, now isn't it?"

Pillow and Sylvia just watched on in exasperation as the crowd began to slowly cut them off from her. It didn't seem an intentional effort- it was too scattershot for that- but it did make things much harder for the two mon who actually KNEW Hannah, and wanted to prevent her identity from being twisted into one of victimhood. Eventually, the crowding got so bad that Sylvia attempted to Slash her way through, only to be instantly bombarded by a crowd of already-riled-up attendees.
Pillow quickly came to her aid, as did Hannah, though the crowd proved hard to beat back. Hannah especially nearly drowned in the swarm, only making her way out of it by creating an entire cage of rocks around her with her Rock Slide attack.

>>53204769
Eventually, however, the trio beat back the majority of the now-rioters. Only a few were left standing- one of which was a small Deerling, unsure of the situation and more than willing to kowtow to Hannah and profusely apologize. She introduced herself as Pansy- a well-liked member of the Cold Storage wilds who'd migrated there from Route 6- before immediately taking responsibility and offering to help the group with any expenses they might accrue as result of the mob.
Thankfully, those totalled to a three-digit number, but the Deerling found herself wanting to stick with the group regardless. So she took them on a tour of the city once the payment was well and done, too. Just for good measure.

From there, the girls reunited with the boys and told of all that'd happened. Their goal returned to beating the gym, though where to go from there... not many of them were sure.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
After their clean victory against Clay, the future of Pillow's team was uncertain.

Everyone was looking to her for input. She was the one who'd wanted to come to Driftveil in the first place, and now she wasn't sure if she'd be leading the team out of it.

Back at Clay's, Tea had evolved. Maybe this was where his conquest for strength would end? And Pillow- she'd received a Moon stone from the miner. It hadn't been used yet, but... it was only a matter of time until that was no longer true.
Nervous, the Munna simply looked to her accomplices.

Hairdo seemed ambivalent to the whole affair, looking moreso in Tea's direction than Pillow's. Hannah just looked *tired,* more in need of a rest than anyone else. She smiled towards Pillow as they locked eyes for just a moment, though it was clearly half-hearted. Sylvia and Tea were talking amongst themselves, both very enthusiastic- Sylvia at Tea's evolution, and Tea at Sylvia's absolute annihilation of Clay's team.

Did they really need her here?
Pillow opened her mouth to suggest something, only for Tea to shout over her. "Come on, let's go to Mistralton! There's no way anything else'll be able to stop me, and I want a challenge!"
Both concrete pillars were raised in triumph as the Conkeldurr exclaimed as much, with Sylvia giggling along with her dodging of them.

Their minds were made up, then.
Pillow huffed, before floating off towards Route 6 with little more than a nod. It took some time until she heard the rest of them follow.

Eventually, the five-man band made it to... a cave? Right, they'd have to go through Chargestone.
Hairdo led the way, making sure the rest were following as he stepped right in. The static atmosphere immediately made his feelers twitch, though he ignored the discomfort in favor of figuring out where exactly they were going. Thankfully, finding that out didn't take too long...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53208723
Floor after floor passed the parade by. Hannah seemed to grow weary with each passing one, increasingly slowing and sometimes wincing for no clear reason at all. All the while, they saw shadows of several different mon, all indistinguishable. The only unifying factor amongst them all was a badge branded with a familiar P.

By the time they'd made it to the deepest parts of the cavern, something was clearly wrong. Aside from Hannah now cringing like she'd suffered some kind of severe injury, Pillow could immediately make out multiple Plasma Grunts lining the halls. All human- all looked semi-lucid, unlike the rabid attackers from before. Looked...

Hannah eventually keeled over, prompting the entire hall to stare daggers in the group's direction. That look only meant one thing- *fight.*
Within seconds, grunts were assailing them on all sides. Sometimes they were accompanied by far more competent Pokémon, sometimes they simply lunged at the group as if they were Pokémon themselves. Fight after fight, battle after battle- the team began to grow weary. But eventually, the circle surrounding Hannah was engulfed in a brilliant red glow-
-and were soon met with the sight of a Gigalith, taking no time at all to join in the fight.

While the entire debacle went down, there was a moment- just a moment- that'd engulfed Pillow and shaken her once more.
Just as the light flashed, she was met with the immediate face of Snorkel, once more. Very clearly in front of her, staring right into her, wearing Plasma gear.

Her immediate reaction was rather obvious. She was going crazy, right? She was going crazy. There was no way he was standing right there.
And yet, once the scarlet glow of her compatriot's evolution dissipated, Snorkel remained. Like a Deerling in the headlights.

And then he was gone, running down the hall like they were never supposed to see him.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53208772
It was only after everyone had long left the cave that Pillow managed to come to her senses.

Tea Burr had ended up restraining her, tired of her attempts to chase after something the Conkeldurr was sure wasn't even there.
Only Sylvia had objected to the idea, and was quickly deterred after seeing just how frantic the Munna had gotten.

That same Munna now lay on a cushion, staring at the ceiling of the Mistralton City Pokemon Center, facing four mon with clear disappointment in their faces.
Behind them stood Skyla, gym leader.
She promptly explained what'd happened since- Pillow had freaked out, only to pass out, and be brought to the center while sometimes kicking in what she could only assume was her sleep.

Pillow sat up instantly, trying to explain the situation in the same frantic tone she usually used. Her team expressed an equally-disapproving response, with Hannah not even looking her in the eyes.
The Munna begged for her to be believed just one more time, only for Skyla to intervene and shake her head. She explained that if this Patrat really was supposed to be dead, then Pillow was likely just having hallucinations. But, she continued, there was a certain place on Route 7 that could help settle this once and for all.

Celestial Tower... that was their next destination.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53208815
The trek to Celestial Tower was a quiet one. Mostly filled with meaningless small talk and cutesy chatter. By now, the team was beginning to realize that there was little reason for them to have a goal- just being together was fun enough for them to go along with it. Though, plenty still found it meaningful to have something to aim for...

...suddenly, Sylvia began to notice a sixth pair of footsteps accompanying theirs. She turned left to see a quiet Audino walking a short distance away from them, seemingly tracing their trail. She paid no mind to him for a little while, but by the time the Tower was in view she began getting suspicious, so the Leavanny stopped a moment and introduced herself to the stranger.

The stranger introduced himself back, naming himself as Potpourri, and claiming to be headed towards Celestial Tower for a relative.
Pillow overheard and floated over, but didn't say anything at first. Nor did Sylvia; she just nodded and gave her apologies, before continuing towards the tower with the rest of the group.

And once they arrived, the long climb upwards began.
There wasn't much trouble, for the most part, save for the soul-sucking candles melted atop many of the graves. Occasionally someone would claim to see an alien, or a trainer near the graves would attack.
Such minor issues eventually began to pile up over time, and around halfway through the tower the team began to tire.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53209835
Once exhaustion began to seep into the group's mood, Potpourri finally spoke up. He offered herbal remedies to the group, and general medical care while they were there. For free.

The team didn't hesitate, and Potpourri got to helping them. He hummed a little tune as he applied tonics and pastes and bandages and berries. He made small talk, gave encouragement, and generally helped everyone press on- before once again fading into the background, with little more than a happy smile on his face.

The quintet was too busy making it to the top to question things. So much so that, when they got there, Pillow was somewhat surprised when Potpourri stepped forward and expressed his intent to ring the bell. Initially, the Munna floated forward to ring the bell herself, but... hesitated.

Potpourri took that as a resignation, and he stepped forward to ring it himself.
Once he did, another Audino came forward- about his height, but noticeably more torn. The two conversed for a time, with Potpourri acting as if the occurrence was completely normal throughout, before stepping back and motioning for Pillow to take the reins.

And so, the Munna floated forward and rang the bell...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53209878
...ring, ring...

The sound echoed throughout the area, and with each ding came forth another spirit. Goggles, Snorkel, Mittens, Tex- each one came forward, all setting their sights on Pillow as the Munna realized just how many other mon she'd seen pass on.

Upon seeing Tex, however, Hannah was the first to come forward, instantly going over to the Sandile to profusely apologize and ask useless questions about his mood or how he was feeling. Tea noticed Mittens and came over to apologize for not listening to the Pansear back in Pinwheel.

Pillow just... stared.
He was really dead, wasn't he?
She didn't know what this meant. Whether she really had lost her mind, or whether the bell was faulty, or... what.
But that didn't matter. In the moment, Snorkel was right there, waiting for her to say something.
And so she did.

Nearly an hour passed before the spirits began to fade. Sylvia and Potpourri hung back while the rest of the team conversed with them- Hairdo eventually coming to join them and talk with both Mittens and Tex. It wasn't easy on any of them- Tea was bawling, Hairdo couldn't help but shed a tear, and even Hannah- though she tried to hide it- wept for Tex.

Pillow...
Pillow seemed fine, at first. Once Snorkel slipped away from her, there was no reaction. Neutrality. Ambivalence.

Before she began to break down.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53209942
Nobody came to her, at first. They weren't sure whether comforting someone who'd gotten them in so much trouble was a good idea, and Hairdo especially had already written her off as having lost her mind a long time ago.

Then Sylvia came over to give her a hug.
Hannah gave her a slight nudge.
Tea came over just to finalize it.

Pillow was almost in disbelief. Both of the hug and of Snorkel. She knew he was gone, and there he was- among the dead. But...
...
...no, that didn't matter.

The Munna simply accepted the hug, remaining in the group's embrace until her tears finally left her.
It was time to move on, and she'd accepted that.

The group eventually began making its way down the stairs. Pillow floated after them, with Potpourri lingering just a little longer to give the bell another look.
As the Munna descended, she figured out the perfect way to leave her more neurotic self behind for good-

-and left Celestial Tower as a Musharna.
From there on out, only two things mattered. That her team was safe, and that the next gym was defeated.
Snorkel could wait.

I am very glad that I can finally put this arc to rest because writing unlikeable characters hurts when they're also delusional and unjustified
Pillow was a shithead whom I gave too much attention, and I am more than happy to move on lmfao
hopefully she wasn't as irritating to read as she was to write lol

>>53210835
The E4 itself was pretty cut and dry, here are the individual kill counts:
Slate - 4
Cobalt - 3
Navy - 2
Bubblegum - 1 (with an assist)
Scarlet - 8 (queen shit)
Periwinkle - 2

Now onto the main event...
Cobalt sang his Perish Song to Gyarados, the two traded blows then we switched in Periwinkle & Aerodactyl. I predicted T!Fang and sent in Slate to a Rock Slide. Now this is where the fun begins. Slate mows down Aero with 2 Rollouts and the injured Gyara with a 3rd. Out comes the first Drago who misses a Dragon Rush and dies to the 4th. Slate then tanks a Rush from the second Drago and steamrolls him with the 5th.

Things are looking amazing, the battle is now 6v2. Lance sends out his ace Drago and I switch in Periwinkle, who is crushed immediately with an Outrage. Scarlet goes in to tank the Outrages and land some Wing Attacks. I bait a Fire Blast and switch into Cobalt, but before my precious froggy can freeze this mf, Drago outspeeds and brutally murders Cobalt w/ Outrage. Scarlet flies back in to repeat the same strat from before. Her health is now yellow and Bubblegum comes in to tank a Fire Blast before Body Slamming Drago. The tyrant is finally dead!

All that's left is Charizard, who spams Air Slash while I counter w/ Milk Drinks and Body Slams when possible. At this point Lance still has all but 1 of his Full Restores, so he heals whenever BG gets Zard down to yellow. BG nerfs him w/ Captivate and paralyzes again, so Zard switches to phys attacks and burns BG w/ Fire Fang, making it harder to wittle his health down. Predicting Dragon Claw, Navy comes out and hits hard w/ Night Slash, then somehow TANKS AN AIR SLASH (thank god for Captivate). Knowing Navy, Scarlet & BG are too weak to finish off Zard, I risk it all on Slate, who eats a Fire Fang and mauls Zard w/ a final Rollout.

Never would I have thought a Donphan would slaughter Lance's almost entire team w/ Rollout. Now to lay two dear friends to rest and prepare for a new journey to Kanto.

posts.com:
After Celestial Tower, it was only a matter of time until another tragedy struck the team.

Unfortunately for them, it came in a terrifying one-two punch.
As they entered Twist Mountain, rumbles could be heard throughout. The team elected to ignore such foreboding, knowing how the mountain was home to many ground-and-rock types, but such a decision would not do them well...

About halfway through their trek, a landslide came after the quintet. They were lucky enough to have a light at the end of the tunnel they were going through.
The very narrow tunnel they were going through.
As the tsunami of earth began chasing the team, Hairdo thought it wise to let the slower mon go first so they wouldn't be crushed. The Unfezant stopped only to ram Tea Burr as hard as he can, making sure he fit through the doorframe and got to the other side, only for his next move to be doing the same to Pillow as she lagged behind.

Unfortunately, during this affair, Hairdo had forgotten to move himself.

He was only alerted to this fact when Sylvia bumped directly into him, shrieking. Turning to see the source of the noise, all Hairdo saw was a tower of dirt and rocks coming down upon both of them.
The last thing he saw was Sylvia vanishing into the debris, as he soon followed suit.


It took Pillow and Hannah nearly half an hour to process what had happened.
Pillow had been staring daggers into the mess of earth that was now spilling out the passageway. Hannah wasn't far behind. Tea Burr was too busy hugging them both to look.
Any day now. Any day, they'd come out. Hairdo would emerge from the pile, holding up Sylvia like a princess, proclaiming their victory.

Any day now...

The rest of the trek through Twist Mountain was silent. Even arriving in Icirrus City and hearing joyous dance music from a travelling troupe couldn't lift the trio's spirits. On a whim, Pillow simply floated over to a Corviknight taxi and prompted the rest of the team to follow her.

The next few weeks were spent resting. The team went back to Nimbasa for some lighthearted entertainment, picking up a Ferroseed along the way who immediately hit it off with Hannah and insisted on staying with them.

From there, they went to Nuvema for a quiet beach vacation far from Undella's loud tourists. While there, Pillow was approached by a kindly Frillish, seemingly having taken an interest in the team, who offered to join after explaining that her school of Frillish had left her behind a few days ago and she had yet to find them- but knew travelling with this group would be a great learning opportunity.
Little hesitation was had in bringing her on board- and so, Dolores accompanied the rest of the crew on their quiet retreat.

It was only after Hannah overheard a pair of Team Plasma Pokémon eagerly discussing the Dragon they were about to awaken in Icirrus that the team felt it pertinent to return to the city and pursue Dragonspiral Tower...

After the mass genocide of Tentacool and Tentacruel, it's time for the only fight in Kanto that matters, Blue.
Leading with Togekiss, two Air Slashes are enough to take out Exeggutor. Just don't get hit by Hypnosis, easy.
Rhydon comes in, switch to Tangrowth and one-shot with Power Whip.
Arcanine, switch to Lanturn, T-Wave and Surf, but we end up taking too much damage forcing a switch to Togekiss to clean up.
Gyarados is a bit unfortunate, since preferably Lanturn could just one-shot. Instead, Togekiss can spam Charm, after which we can go to Weezing and T-bolt from there.
Pidgeot lives a T-bolt from Weezing, forcing a switch to Mamoswine to Ice Shard the remainder of its health.
Just Machamp left. I don't have a good plan here, so I throw in a Blizzard, dealing a decent amount of damage before almost dying to Dynamic Punch.
I decide to make a risky play here and switch to Lanturn to bait an Earthquake so I can safely go into Togekiss. If it doesn't work out, I'll still be able to bring in Togekiss regardless.
For some reason Machamp goes for Stone Edge instead of another Dynamicpunch, allowing Lanturn to barely live. The switch to Togekiss isn't completely safe here based on that interaction, because Machamp sees a KO with every move or something. I go for it anyways, and luckily get the EQ I need. Air Slash wins from here.

That was gross and bad. Anyways, just Red left then.

>>53205695
>>Instead of the usual amnesia human-turned-to-pokemon, what would you do to change up the formula?

In terms of the mechanics, make the self-insert protagonist a bit like the Elder scrolls protagonist. Meaning, you pick your starter, and then the story begins by you arriving in a new town by ship (or Lapras, I don't care) or something like that. You get some dialogue options regarding your background, but other than that, the game never mentions your past and never makes a big deal about it.
Make the partner an interesting charcter with a deep backstory to compensate.


Also, make the games more relaxed. Let me do the main story at my own pace, give me plenty of optional side missions, give me a more diverse range of jobs.

In terms of story, make the game take place where the humans have been extinct for a couple hundered years or so. The dungeons are mostly set in the leftovers of human society, like overgrown cities, skyscrapers and so on. Imagine exploring the rusty remains of a giant cruise ship.
Only a few select Pokemon with extremly long livespans have been around the time humans existed, the rest views the humans like Skyrim views the Dwemer.
The narrative would then revolve around researching the remains of human society and find out what brought its doom.

>>53213953
You guys need to git gud. I played as a Machop and have already evolved him into a Machamp. Never died a single time against any of the bosses.

Machop is one of the best ones to play as, because of how useful he is in the dungeon floors. He has moves that does significant damage like Karate Chop and Low Kick (especially useful against bosses due to the weight bonus) PLUS he has STAB bonus so he does a lot of damage. And his moves have a lot of PP.
In the boss battles, if you have the moves linked with Leer at the top, your damage increases exponentially by the fourth turn.

Here's how to beat bosses with Machop.
1. Have Charmander as a partner who knows Smokescreen. Scary Face is optional.
2. Switch Charmander's IQ to exclusive move user and only set Smokescreen (other moves are fine if you have them linked).
3. Have all of Machop's moves linked with Leer on top. Even better if Machop is holding Power Band. Do NOT forget Low Kick. It is especially useful against bosses.
4. Smokescreen in the PMD will give the opponent whiffer status so they will miss every move for a certain amount of turns. So you have no fear of getting hit by a flying type move.
5. You will have defeated the boss in 5-6 turns after a barrage of linked moves.
6. Carry 2-3 revival seeds in case you get unlucky, but you probably won't. I have fainted in dungeon floors but never against a boss.

Machop and Charmander are my favourite duo to play as in PMD rescue team. The type disadvantage against bosses is really easy to get over if you know how to play the game.
And the type disadvantage only matters before postgame where most bosses are flying types.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53216272
>it doesn't even have a high critrate lmao
Machop learns Focus Energy before level 10. That already gives him a high crit rate.
My moveset when I fought Rayquaza was Leer, Focus Energy, Karate Chop and Low Kick. I carry two Max Elixirs and 1 link box every time I have to fight a boss. Max Elixirs are easy to obtain through shops and aren't very expensive and Link Boxes can be farmed in Lapis Cave/Mt Blaze.
>Linking your entire moveset together might work, but you've got no kind of versatility
This is an advantage for Machop, not a weakness. Bulbasaur has sleep powder and stuff but it's useless in dungeon floors against 10-15 critters. Machop's moves have high PP and can one shot critters. This works in his favor because you can survive long dungeons, especially in early game.
>Also if you're gonna just use Smokescreen you may as well pick a better protag.
I always pick Charmander as my partner because Smokescreen is that valuable. Scary Face is also useful against Groudon and Rayquaza.

In my experience, regular dungeon floors have always been tougher than boss battles. PMD is a game of attrition, and Machop is excellent at attrition. Also isn't the point of having a partner covering for your weaknesses? Charmander is a great cover for your weakness with its Smokescreen.

>>53216936
More variety in dungeons. I would take inspiration from the otherwise godawful Etrian Mystery dungeon, for example. In this one, dungeons aren’t linear – often there are two or three stairs leading to the next level. You can freely go back and forth, which you will need to do, since sometimes a floor is a dead end without a staircase, meaning you have to backtrack and find a path that leads further down. Also, one or more superbosses hunt you through the dungeon.
To counterbalance this, you can build fortification structures within a dungeon that (a) lock the overall layout of the dungeon, (b) let you start at those fortifications instead of floor 1 and (c) provide a stopgap for these superbosses – you can even put otherwise inactive team members in those fortifications so that this B-Team then fights the superboss if it hits that floor.
I wouldn’t make every dungeon like this. Sometimes you want just the linear experience. What I am asking for is variety.
Also, we need more variety in jobs. Sky did this pretty well with Outlaws, since they act as a kind of mini-boss or even a monster house you can prepare for. The regular jobs need improvement though.

>>53214930
I appreciate that you're actually trying to start a conversation. And I love it. I think that, in my ideal world, it would have still been the GSC that we got but there would have been some modern style integration of the betamons back into the fold either in Crystal or something like Stadium 2. Not all of them, but the more interesting ones. I would have loved to see whatever that original canine legendary was as well as the tigers, wolfman and a few others. Some of those designs are actually really cool and I think they would have completely changed the trajectory of the franchise. Maybe I'll get some disagreement and even hate for saying this, but I remember when RS came out and the dex was leaking because I'm that fucking old. A lot of those Pokémon did not look like Pokémon and I remember at the time the internet community was sort of divided on whether they were really cool or the series had jumped the shark. And I wonder if they stuck to their guns with the beta Pokémon from GSC if that would not have happened. A lot of those designs definitely had more of a goofy, generic RPG monster and sort of fun feel to them. But once Generation 3 came out, we started seeing more Pokémon that were directly inspired by a specific animal/mythology and a lot more Pokémon who were monstrous or "complex." And we never really went totally back

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53214932
The series really would have gone in a different direction of this was closer to the end product. So many of these beta designs fall into the "goofy" territory and look like any generic anime/JRPG Monster, like all of the bunny looking things, the scarecrow bird, or several of the babies. Then you get random tough looking monsters like the scorpion or Viking boat, which seem honestly out of place next to everything else. And we also have what appears to be a line with four stages with that dryad looking Pokemon. Ultimately I'm ok with what we really got bc it had a more healthy mix that leaned into having monsters that looked more tough and I think it helped develop more of that essence that modern Pokémon have, which sets them apart from the other '90s JRPGs. But if we continued down the path of the beta seems to be taking us, I think the series would have become much different and probably have more of a DQ Monsters or Demikids feel than how it is today.

Picrel is what I threw together after trying to make a saltrock lizard concept of my own, ended up moving towards a stegosaurus mixture since its back panels would work well with salt crystals forming from sunlight and spike tails just makes it more menacing. If you find this strays too far from the theme all three have in common then I'll just keep this one to myself.

>>53219987
bdsp has a tool that can view a webcam/capture card. it counts your character's blinks, and then from that it tells you what second to start a battle in (using honey in grass). there's some areas like the trophy garden and caves where there's almost no randomness, so i got it on the third try basically as i was still getting the tool set up properly. i followed this guide but there's lots on yt:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tBONus3Kg8U&t=18s
(he screams like a moron at the start hence the timestamp but then the tutorial is really good, links to some good docs too)
if you want the daily spawn in trophy garden, you'll need to set pokefinder to show only encounter slot 6 (7 for yesterday's mon as they apparently stay for two days, who knew)

swsh tool doesn't use footage, you feed in a list of 1s and 0s depending on the attack animations that display in menus, but i haven't tried that one yet. sounds easier if you know your secret id, harder if you don't as you need to catch a shiny to reverse engineer your secret id:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CLbW96E-9YA

>How hard would it be to catch Route 1 mons? Cave, water, forest encounters? Pseudos assuming you can find them?
(assuming you mean in general and not based off of Pokémon that'd live where I live or something) Route 1 would be piss easy. Literally just set out some food for a Rattata or some shit and bam, you have your mon. Rock types in caves would probably also be about as easy as picking them up and not harming them (the bats would be way harder for obvious reasons), Pseudos would probably bite your hand off before you could even try, etc. The games give a pretty good estimation of how easy it is to catch any given thing with catch rates; pretty sure they're not meant to be literal representations of how good the ball is, but instead catch-alls to signify the difficulty level of what you're attempting to catch.
>Would (you) find a Pokémon useful in your current job?
I'm still studying but trying to get something at minimum wage to support myself. I think a Pokémon would be more useful for studying than any job I could get at the moment. Then again, just having *someone* there for me would help, so maybe that doesn't count...
>Do all Pokémon speak the same language? To what extent can they communicate with humans?
I go along with pic rel as a headcanon because I think it makes sense considering Mew and it keeps a bit of mystique around the Pokémon instead of just making them "literally animals with superpowers".
>How do trainer battles handle the concept of the victor being awarded cash? How does it affect the economy?
It's probably just common courtesy. I like to think it started as a dare amongst kids and just stuck around when those kids grew up. It's probably not set in stone as a law or anything.
>Any region you'd settle down in? Which town?
Hoenn, probably in Lilycove. The Safari Zone is fun, the city looks gorgeous, contests are right there if you want them. I think it's just situated and built very nicely in an already-nice region.

/vpwt/ - Reality vs Expectation edition
>post fanfics you like
>share your own fics, ask for advice, post story updates
>discuss writerly struggles with fellow writefriends

Previous Thread: >>53154813

Check out the catalog for a directory of fics from fellow writefags: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1PtN4D_9CSw8JJ9uO6v0oQqdtKEkS8aFAvfxqI96XfSE
Gallery of art drawn for stories in the thread: https://imgur.com/a/sjdck

>Can I post NSFW fics?
There are no rules against NSFW text links.

>How should I post my fics?
If it's short enough to fit into a couple of posts, posting to the thread is fine. If you want to share longer works, or if you want more permanent storage, you can link to a host: fanfiction.net, AO3, Pastebin, or Google Docs.

>I'm not a writer but I want to contribute
Feel free to give stories posted a read and critique as you see fit. Keep it relevent to the story.
>Can I request something?
You're encouraged to post prompts, i.e. short snippets or greentext sequences describing your ideas. You can also expand on prompts posted by others. If writing an entire story from start to finish feels too daunting, this is a way to get started.

>I have this idea about [event/technology/...]
Feel free to post your thoughts about how specific parts of the Pokémon world function as well. Worldbuilding is always welcome.

>Can I add a fic I wrote to the catalog?
Check the catalog for the submission link. Fill out the form with all the necessary information and it will be submitted for review automatically.

We're also looking to collect ideas for fanfics as a resource for stumped writers. Feel free to throw an idea out there; someone may choose to use it themselves!
Ideabin: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1X072SSWulcC6RJRrPA6v9XtyohRybvMBl6Fh49wHsRw

>>53217040

>>53216627
Pokemon are vehicles for human conflict. They're never the focus of the plot, they're the gimmick of the setting. Like magic in the HP universe. The games, the show, whatever, they all focus on the human characters and their struggles, because that's what the audience really wants to see., pokemon are little more than animals in canon.

There's nothing *wrong* with exclusively focusing on people, and you shouldn't think otherwise unless you're a furfag writing PMD shit, in which case have at it I guess, but don't conflate the importance of pokemon in a spinoff where all of humanity is gone (the containment series for the dogfuckers, essentially) to the mainline universe, where they're glorified magic dogs.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53216817
It takes place near a canon region but not in one. There's little ties, like how a character has ties to a group from that region, but I want to keep them separate vistas. It's always taken me out of fanfiction when it leans too heavily on canon stuff or characters, because you know that's not what the "real" version of that stuff would be like. I tried to keep to the naming conventions of that region though.

>>53217040
>>53217085
I do want it to be a Pokemon story since that's the key part of the story; the main character doesn't have a Pokemon and you find out the details of why and how that ties into the conflict throughout. Putting aside that I'm worried about boring my Pokemon readers by not having enough Pokemon, the other thing I'm more worried about from a story standpoint is making it feel like the world is alive around the main character and moving past him in a way he's not really a part of since he has no Pokemon. Reading through my story it sometimes feels a little jarring to me how I can have a straightforward interrogation scene or a fight and then a Pokemon shows up

Sorry I'm sort of spitballing here. I'm trying to figure out what I'm doing and it helps to put it in words.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53217186
I think in most instances you are just overthinking it. You should be featuring pokemon as a whole, likely as setting dressing in the background or making a quick point to your character arc before moving on, but there is nothing stopping you from just writing about humans doing human things in the world. Keep in mind that if you genuinely feel like they aren't prevalent enough in your early plot, that is a change you are going to have to make.

Have pokemon outside. Have pokemon on TV. Have pokemon advertisements. Have other people with pokemon. Describe the character's feelings regarding these things. Things in passing, but things that are there.

>>53215612
defenders usually have some "good" displacement moves, they're defenders because they defend the goals

a defender will prevent enemies from scoring (pushing them away) but they can be used offensively from pushing the enemies away from their own goal (for example, if an eleki is walking toward the enemy goal, you can use your displacement moves to push them away and let eleki in)
due to their nature, they're designed to be inherently bulkier than the average character, at the cost of having lower damaging capabilities. Because of this, when not defending a goal, their purpose is to act as a frontline for their teammates, using their dislodging capabilities to push away enemies targeting the frail attackers in your team.

but due to unite's nature, your teammates will have shit in their diapers, and your efforts to protect them from harm will lead to absolutely fucking nothing as they'll be too busy eating boogers to take advantage of you tanking for them, and rather than attacking they'll simply watch you die right in front of them as they mindlessly go back to farming baltoys instead.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>53220046
In SoloQ, you need to have some amount of trust with randoms. You can't literally do everything in the game, You need to trust that maybe your Defender will walk in front of you and check a bush so your Pikachu doesn't have to, or that your high DPS player will rip the Regi objectives while the enemy team is distracted by the All-Arounder+Defender fighting them. You have to hope that your random knows how to secure an objective with Dragon Pulse if needed, things like that. It's frustrating when you have two teammates pushing into a T2 goal at the 2:10 mark, but it's frustrating because you HOPED they would be smart enough not to do that.

For more context, a Zoroark and Absol pushed the top goal and backcapped, so even if I had stayed on the goal as Deci, there is no guarantee I wouldn't have gotten my ass blasted by both of them (since again, I had no Ult and the Mime did) and we still could've lost if Mime didn't jump the top.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53218839
>beating them in pokemon battles, taking their money,
That isn't revenge; you're kids playing a game and the rules of the game state that the winner gets cash. Only a select few characters make Pokemon battles about malice, and these characters are always portrayed as bad, or in Silver's case, misguided.

>Violence and revenge should never be the answer. If you kill your enemies then morally you're just as bad as they are. Not to mention, if you kill a murderer out of revenge, then the amount of killers in the world remains the same.
The player character never kills anyone in any of the games. The international police are investigating Team Rocket, so you can assume they're arrested if caught. Moreover, you can still talk to Rocket Grunts after you beat them. In later generations, the Admins even complain about how cute you are/are in denial about it after you beat them, so the player character can't be some terrifying or extremely malicious force. They're an anime hero.

>The thing about taking down these "criminal" organizations is that you don't take their feelings into consideration.
In at least one case (probably most) Red is defending himself from Team Rocket. The guy on Nugget Bridge is clearly extorting him. He only becomes the aggressor in Lavender, Celadon, and Saffron, and in two of those cases, he is saving someone who is at a very real risk of being physically harmed.

>>53218908
>As if none of the members of the team are even human beings. Maybe they joined out of desperation, or economic hardship. Why did these teams even form in the first place? Does anyone even care about these people as individuals?
Yes. Saturn takes over Team Galactic and says that maybe they really should research new forms of energy instead of lying about it. The Grunts clearly respect him, and he clearly cares about the well-being of the company and society.

Hypothetical here - say I'm playing against a room full of Lugia drones who don't know the game rules and just buy whatever BDIF list topped the last regionals. Now I know that Banette (Vivid Voltage)'s Curse of Devolution only works on evolved Pokemon that have a lower stage beneath and wouldn't remove Archeops from play. But say my opponent(s) doesn't and assumes sending their Archeops back to hand with it to be a correct and legal play.
How long could you get away with this? Could you claim plausible deniability? Can you at least partially shift the blame onto your opponent for not knowing the rules and allowing the incorrect game state and confirming my win? You could likely farm locals doing this and maybe day 1 of a regionals, but I imagine if you ever got judge checked or made it far enough they might suspect malice and DQ you anyway.
I doubt it'd actually be feasible to pull this off but it'd be an interesting experiment in game knowledge checks. Moreso seeing which players come to big events and do and don't know their rulings

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
BW > BW2
BW2 isn’t bad, but it seems like a clear attempt to pander to the people who hated BW (via adding national dex mons right from the beginning, adding more tutorials, a battle frontier-life, etc) and 80% of it is still BW with no change outside of a few encounter spots, Route 4, and some minor endgame stuff. I would’ve preferred at least a bit more overhauling of Unova; as is, after I get to Castelia the game feels extremely stale to me all the way until Reversal Mountain.
I also find that the music is generally worse, and I really dislike almost all of the character designs. The protagonists look insanely retarded, and your rival (alongside Marlon) looks equally-as dumb. Bianca’s glasses don’t fit her and her wardrobe seems to clash with itself.
Story is also worse, with Hugh never shutting up about the Purrloin to the point of being one-note, and having Plasma as some dumb terrorists again kills any impact they could’ve had when their goal was actually interesting in the originals.
The games also hold your hand a significant amount more in BW2 than in the original, to the point where you’re still getting tutorials after the second fucking gym leader, and they started a lot of trends that make modern games such a slog (excessive handholding and tutorials, bloated regional dexes, dual third versions instead of just one, etc)
BW2 may be better in many traditional aspects (more longevity through side activities like the PWT and Pokestar Studios, more variety in wild encounters, arguably a better difficulty curve) but I prefer BW since it just seems much tighter and definitely a lot more ambitious. BW2 just feels like a defeated resignation to the rabid fans who were screeching about charizard and pikachu being missing from the originals.

>>USUM is worse because it's literally remaking a game a year later to put in additions that hindered the plot even more and ruined a good story with some nonsense.
The plot is worse, but that's the literal only thing. Areas getting face-lifts to make them more substantial like Kala'e Bay and Victory Road, the changes to story fights making them more challenging, waking back on some of the weird design choices with SOS battles and Vikavolt/Crabrawler's late evos, new mons on TOP of forms, a new Battle Facility (Agency was gimmicky as shit but it was pretty fun when it was active), more side activities like Warp Ride, Mantine Surf, and Photo Club, etc.
Also Rainbow Rocket didn't "rape" anything that wasn't already established by ORAS's multiverse talk. The villain's motivations and characterizations were consistent and it didn't break anything in the main story proper. Ir wasn't a masterpiece, but it was perfectly serviceable as an extra bit of fanservice to send off the handheld era of Pokemon. And ven if you disagree with all of that, it's literally just an extra dungeon to explore and more battles to do-quite a few of which were even decently challenging

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53212128
An idea and a suggestion of a concept is better than nothing at all.

Team Galactic felt so empty in DP. At that point in the franchise, it felt like they were there being an evil team and doing evil deeds for its own sake. Because a Pokémon game needs an evil team. That's the formula. In Platinum they tried to flesh out Cyrus and Galactic a little more, but I don't understand most of what the rank and file grunts were doing or what they personally gained from it.

Team Rocket didn't need lofty goals or justification because they were a criminal gang. That was it. The crime and personal gain was the point.

RSE tried to give Aqua/Magma something slightly more nuanced, being some breed of environmental activists turned extremists. It was dumb, excessive and nonsensical, but I at least understand the core idea. I think this was also the point where "evil team wants world domination" was truly cemented in the franchise.

Team Plasma were such a breath of fresh air. Their objective as it is presented at first has moral ambiguity and the morality of the franchise's core mechanic has been questioned for years outside the game. The fact that GF would even dare to entertain the idea was bold for a franchise founded on YOU GOOD, ENEMY TEAM BAD ironically black and white morality.

Of course, it was secretly that very morality at the core of Plasma in the end. N as the puppet leader was true to his convictions, but even he is forced to go through the whole I WRONG, PROTAGONIST RIGHT revelation.

So it was a step in the right direction. A step is better than standing still. And BW2 did explore the other side of these ideas much better.

Such a shame that the very next game reverted to French Ganondorf's nonsensical plan to destroy the world. There were brief shades of a deeper idea with his hatred of people taking advantage of good intentions, but again the grunts don't reflect this idea.

"Oh, you are not as fashionable as me? Guess you deserve to die!"

posts.name: Anonymous

>>53213490
Who said that gen 5 executed its ideas flawlessly? The games have plenty of issues I could criticise. I did criticise them in my post, and lamented that it didn't execute on them properly.

I disagree with your contention that the previous games executed on their ideas successfully. They sold well, admittedly declining since gen 1. (Indeed the franchise has only started to reach gen 1 levels of sales on the Switch.) But selling well on one formula does not mean that that formula is a good one, that it cannot be improved or that it should be followed in the future.

As I said, gen 1 (and 2 since it was virtually a sequel to 1 in the way GF were handling the franchise at that point. It was expected to be the last game.) could get by with its more primitive story given the limits of the platform, the fact that it was the first one and there was no established formula and Team Rocket's ambitions did not go beyond crime for profit. Giovanni hinted at world domination, but that may have been blustering or hyperbole on his part. We only had a few lines on dialogue to go off and the actions of the team as a whole rarely went beyond petty crime, verging on terrorism at times.

RSE tried to give the teams a grander, ethical and planetspanning goal, but I already spoke on the flaws with that.

Gen 4 arrived when the franchise was in something of a slump. Not selling poorly, usually topping charts and selling in the millions. But compared to previous heights, a low point. DPPt followed the same formula and morality as previous games. Team bad, you good, get gym badges, defeat team, become champion, credits. Nowhere did it suggest that Galactic were in the right or there might be moral questions. And again, what did the grunts get out of Cyrus' plan that he quickly told you at the end of the game? Did they even know it?

I feel Team Flare are Team Galactic again. Did most grunts even know the plan? They talk about fashion in most encounters.

>>53214533
Well, setting for starters.
When I play Gen 1, I like the urban setting. It feels very city like. The remake brough us the Sevii Islands, but they feel very last though.
I like Gen 2 because it's like I went to rural land. Kanto is the capital, Johto is the countryside.
While I understand the complains about too much water, I like Hoenn's good land division. First you are in forests, then in caves and inner land, suddenly you are walking under volcano ash or the desert. Then you are crossing marshlands all the way to the sea. And even the sea has the undersea connections. And if you were the curious sort, you had the fast currents in the south. There's a lot to find in Hoenn.
While is very slow and boring, I appreciate Sinnoh. If you could backtrack easy in Mt Coronet, it could be a great hub to travel the land. I like the interesting divisions of city and rural countryside, and I have to admit that the swamp and snow were interesting. Annoying, but interesting. NTA by my unpopular opinion is the Johto's stories is one the the only good ones, and nearly every story after is a waste of time or makes no sense.

Gen 3
Was apparently based on a real life debate, but wasn't communicated well. and just makes Magma/Aqua look like far stupider than they should have. Archie wants MORE water in the region with the most water, and Maxie wants to create more land for people by erupting a landlocked volcano that would end up destroying Fallarbor.

Gen4
One of the most nonsensical stories ever. Apparently Galactic's members are either don't care that Cyrus wants to destroy the world, or are too dumb to realize what's going on. Also, despite begin a "proper" villain team, they're even less organized that "Team' Rocket leftovers" from GSC. Most of what they do has no connection. Also they set off a fucking bomb and no one in the region cares.
Platinum "tries" to fix it but its still not very good. Also Looker is added but the only thing he accomplishes is arresting Charon, who seems to have been written in solely to take the blame so that the "pretty" Galactic admins can evade punishment.

Gen 5
Plasma's "Liberate Pokémon" spiel is clearly a ruse to disarm Unova so they can take over, that part makes sense. However, the game ends up raising genuine questions about the ethics of catching Pokemon that we're just supposed to ignore because Plasma happens to be evil.

Gen 6
Similar issues with as Gen 4, Also Tries to claim that there is poverty and lack or resources in Pokemon's utopian world, and the only evidence of this is a single character that's post game only.

Gen7,
The first "good" story but only if you accept that you're jsut Lillie's sidekick in Lillie's Family Drama Show. And Lusamine is by far the best villain, but of course Game Freak can't leave well enough alone and USUM defangs Lusamine fr no reason. Also what the fuck was going on with Rainbow Rocket?

Gen 8
HAHAHAHAHAHHA

Gen 9
haven't played

>>53216614
>One of the most nonsensical stories ever. Apparently Galactic's members are either don't care that Cyrus wants to destroy the world, or are too dumb to realize what's going on.
It is neither. They don't know what's going on because they were lied to. They're researching new forms of energy presumably for the sake of a civilization that's already there, or at the very least a new world order within the corporeal world they already know. Even the higher ranking members don't know Cyrus actually plans to remake the universe because he just never told them.

That isn't stupid in context. They already view Pokemon as a source of energy, which is why they steal Clefairy and also why they target Rowan in Jubilife (they want his research on evolution because they want to harness the energy released during it), so going after a Legendary Pokemon to them is like going after a massive source of energy.

>Also they set off a fucking bomb and no one in the region cares.
Cynthia says that she didn't take Team Galactic seriously because of the ridiculous things that they say, and IIRC, because of how they look (I know for sure other NPCs comment on how weird they look, I just don't remember if Cynthia was one of them) but she starts getting more interested in them because of the violent acts they keep committing. People do care about Team Galactic being violent, but they are stopped shortly after the bombs go off. Consider also that their headquarters in Veilstone is just Cyrus' company. Until the bombs go off, they don't do any bad shit in central Sinnoh; they do their shady shit primarily around the outskirts/the lakes.

Lastly, the presence of Looker in Platinum at least indicates that Interpol was investigating Team Galactic.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53206276
Here's my take on types:

Bug-type
- Bug no longer resists Fighting.
- Bug now resists Psychic.

Electric-type
- Electric is now weak to Ghost.

Fairy-type
- Fairy no longer resists Bug.
- Fairy is now weak to Grass and Psychic.

Fighting
- Fighting no longer resists Bug.

Ghost-type
- Ghost no longer resists Bug.
- Ghost now resists Electric.

Grass-type
- Grass is now immune to Fairy.

Ground-type
- Ground is no longer weak to Water.
- Ground is now weak to Steel.

Ice-type
- Ice now resists Ground and Flying

Psychic-type
- Psychic now resists Fairy.

Water-type
- Water is now weak to Poison.

Rock-type
- Rock is no longer weak to Grass.

Steel-type
- Steel is now weak to Electric.
- Steel is no longer immune to Poison, it just resists it, but it remains immune to Poison status.

>>53213910
Gen 3 stores Pokemon by a three-digit hexadecimal number. Thus the highest number you could possibly have without rewriting everything would be 4,096.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53213910
>>53213929
The Pokemon id is internally a 16-bit number so you could have 65535 Pokemon, but you would run out of ROM space with sprites and cries way before that. Same with moves. Abilities are limited to 256.

Since you have the source code for the game, you could change the data types used to increase the limits, making ROM space the only hard limit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
While it is not known to evolve into or from any other Pokémon, Castform has the ability to change forms depending on the current weather.

During normal weather, fog, a sandstorm, or a shadowy aura, it is in Normal form and is a Normal type.
During harsh sunlight, it is in Sunny Form and is a Fire type.
During rain, it is in Rainy Form and is a Water type.
During hail it is in Snowy Form and is an Ice type.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
While it is not known to evolve into or from any other Pokémon, Rotom has the ability to possess the motors of certain appliances and change forms. It also learns a new move depending on which appliance it possesses.

When it does not possess an appliance, (or, in Generation VIII and Generation IX, is possessing a light bulb) it is dual-type Electric/Ghost and learns Thunder Shock if the move it had in its other forms is the only move it knows.
When it possesses a microwave oven, it becomes Heat Rotom, is dual-type Electric/Fire, and learns Overheat.
When it possesses a washing machine, it becomes Wash Rotom, is dual-type Electric/Water, and learns Hydro Pump.
When it possesses a refrigerator, it becomes Frost Rotom, is dual-type Electric/Ice, and learns Blizzard.
When it possesses an electric fan, it becomes Fan Rotom, is dual-type Electric/Flying, and learns Air Slash.
When it possesses a lawn mower, it becomes Mow Rotom, is dual-type Electric/Grass, and learns Leaf Storm.

We deserve GF putting in the work to make lively, reborn open world experiences of the classic generations, but we will never receive it. Johto will get a Chibi remake and a barebones legends game, Unova will get a Chibi remake and a barebones legends game, Kalos, Alola, and Galar will probably only show back up through DLC/Events and not even get the properly remade at all. It’s not what should happen, but it’s clearly what will happen.

>>53215729
They’re literally not 1:1 remakes, I don’t know what you want me to tell you other than “play games before making easily debunked claims about them”. Yeah it’s the remake with the closest experience to the original, but it’s not a literal 1:1 remake. The underground is totally redesigned with spawn labyrinths that include Pokemon you could never obtain in DP along with earlier methods of obtaining rarer Pokemon. It completely changed the excavation mechanics to have an impact on held items, shiny hunting, and the post game. The Pal Park is changed into a legendary crossover arena with a soulful fetch quest referencing the physical carts of the classic games. The Elite Four and Gym leaders have been redone with the most competent trainer AI in the series to incorporate actual battle strategies and smart item use into NPC battles, and it actually has cool rematches to incorporate both the underloved DP teams and the iconic Platinum teams. It’s okay to not like BDSP, I thought they were forgettable and kinda lame, but so were the original DP, it’s so disingenuous to say that they changed nothing just because you don’t like what they changed. It changes about as much from the core story and adds about as much to the postgame as FRLG and people don’t shit their pants over those games, I think BDSP was just a mass awakening for a lot of people to the fact that DP were not great games then and they’re even worse games now. Ultimately if I feel like replaying Gen 4 I’m probably gonna do BD; they may largely be the same game, but BDSP is light speed compared to Gen 4, it was basically an optimized port which I’ll take as someone who never had any nice things to say about Sinnoh. I’ll say it again: any complaint at BDSP is a misguided complaint towards DP, a professionally painted portrait of explosive diarrhea is still gonna be a pile of shit at the end of the day, no matter how pretty they make it.

>>53213438
I haven't played PMD since I was a teenager, I'm pretty sure, but there's simply more effort put into the narrative than in the mainline games. The player character being turned into a Pokemon presents a mystery that revolves around them, and IIRC, they actually have thoughts and stuff you can see and read. In the mainline games, things are a bit more nebulous with the Protagonist. Sure the player themselves is expected to beat the League because they have to in order for the game to be over, and the player CHARACTER has been asked to complete the Pokedex/stop an evil organization, but it always feels like the story is happening around that character and not like it is about them, wherein Mystery Dungeon, this is simply not true. At least in Explorers of Time/Darkness. The player character has a complex history, relationships that feel substantial, and a goal they were chasing prior to the beginning of the story. Mystery Dungeon also has twists, and more fleshed out characters; in fact everyone's personalities shine a little better because they're not just sprites, they have portraits and stuff.

If you think Mystery Dungeon isn't that impressive, that's fine, but that just means the mainline games (which I prefer because I don't like playing as a talking Pokemon that much) are even less impressive.

posts.com:
X/Y and DPPt have a lot in common, but I don't think people discuss where they differ enough. Team Galactic may be silly, but they're still pleasing enough to look at, and all of their top brass look cool, or failing that, respectable: as far as anime characters go, none of them are totally repellent. Team Flare looks dumb, their leader looks outrageous, and their admins are redundant. There are five of them, and they're all basically interchangeable grunts from what I recall. If I'm wrong, please tell me. Malva and Xerosic are the only ones who look cool, and in Xerosic's case, it's only because he's scary looking, which is good for a villain in his position. But Xerosic goes from nasty to just plain weird in the post-game. He's kind of inconsistent. I guess he likes science, but he seems genuinely enthralled by Lysandre's genocidal machinations.

Speaking of those, Lysandre seems way crazier and more malicious than Cyrus. What he intends is nothing but murder for the sake of aesthetics. The way he and everybody else who’s in on it talk about his plan just makes him seem like a complete lunatic. One could argue that Cyrus is also chasing after a certain aesthetic, sure, fine, whatever, but the poise with which he presents his true aspirations makes him seem more level-headed and less like a raving lunatic. Like this is something he actually thought through, whereas with Lysandre it’s just, for lack of a better term, melodramatic schizobabble capsizing into a pity party. In short, Cyrus is more dignified. There’s also the way the Gen 4 characters note that Cyrus himself cannot escape the “spirit” he detests so thoroughly. Gen 4 raises a lot of questions about the human condition that Gen 6 does not – at least, as far as I recall.

Lastly, Cyrus doesn't speak of sparing the chosen ones or anything like that. He's thinking on a higher level than Lysandre, who at best seems to be thinking of creating an ideal country, as opposed to an ideal world.

>>53208188
The game trying to give you a challenge without being impossibly hard is bad design now?

The way the level curve is setup means that there are two main challenges throughout the story, which are the elite 4 (level 40-50 while the player is level 30-40) and red (level 77-81 while the player is level 50-60). There are other challenges in the game like whitney, clair, blue, or silver but they're not overlevelled at all.

Both cases make total sense given what they are meant to represent, and yet are still beateable without grinding if the player has a good strategy (red can even be beaten with level 5 mons). At most, you could complain that it takes a long time to match red's pokemon levels, but that's exactly the point - he has been training there for years without talking to his mom, he better have an impressive team to show for it. If you raise the level curve to match the players level with his he doesn't look mpressive at all (like the fiasco that was diatha as a champion), and if you max out red's level to preserve the difficulty you make it impossible for less talented players to outgrind him.

While there are problems with gen 2, the level curve isn't one of them (even though it would be nice for the game to adjust the levels dynamically)

posts.name: Anonymous

>>53206404
I imagine the process after capturing a Pokemon is something along the lines of;
>capture
>win trust, travel and care for it, battle weaker mons it wants to fight on its own (several months)
>begin to coordinate, communicate more effectively, it follows basic commands now (up to another year)
>trainer battles, care to avoid constant fainting as it can lose trust in your abilities
>potential evolution in another year or several depending on the mon
By then you'd have invested minimum 3 years into a decently strong Pokemon, potentially less (Route 1 encounters) or more (Baby pseudos, fished up Pokemon). So it does make more sense to buy an Egg from a breeder for your kid, because I doubt pet mons like Meowth/Glameow would be partial to battling just because you grew up with them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53208120
Gulf coast area. There was a lot of prep building up to getting into the waters, and most of it was in pools and lakes nearby at camping areas.
I definitely didn't think it was anywhere near enough preparation. It gave off a vibe of high-school cheerleading with how fucking insane it was safety-wise. Rip tides, jellyfish stings, the occasional shark. The danger is real.
We had a full staff keeping an eye at all times, and luckily nothing too bad ever happened, but it's still scary.
It did a lot of good for the kids, but it could have been so bad so often.
I still get postcards years later from them, now as adults, saying it was a turning point in their lives. Which is awesome. Just like. Damn.
